Description#1: Matthew Dale describes the difficulties that he experienced while traveling west to the Rocky Mountains where he planned on mining a fortune and gaining good health. After traveling up the Missouri River to Fort Leavenworth, Kansas, Matthew learned that he was two weeks early to travel through the Plains. While waiting near Fort Leavenworth, Matthew commented that he is enjoying the country west of the Missouri River. At the end of his letter, Matthew stated that once he has reached the Rocky Mountains, his family will need to send his letters to Denver City, Kansas Territory.

Description#1: As Matthew traveled west to Council Grove from Fort Leavenworth, he was able to write to his brother and describe his travel west. While traveling west, Matthew wrote he traveled from daylight until night. While reporting good traveling conditions, Matthew also writes that there are conflicting reports about the mines, but he remains positive that he will successfully mine a fortune. Matthew describes that they are on the Santa Fe road which passed through area where the Kaw Indians lived. With the constant traveling, Matthew wrote that his traveling party still has 110 miles to reach Denver City.

Description#1: During the beginning days in the Kansas Territory, Matthew took a job at a saw mill, but once winter passes Matthew wrote that he planned to resume his travels. While waiting for winter to pass, Matthew was able to live with Thomas Giddings, who provided Matthew with information of the surrounding area. Matthew joined Thomas and helped mine his claims. While mining the men find several coal veins, but to continue to mine the coal, it was necessary to build a ditch. Since both men did not have enough money, Matthew wrote home to his family asking them to send money and personal letters.

Description#1: After prospecting to find a mining location, Matthew decided to sell the land and purchase claims in another area. Although there was hope of earning money in the new claim, it was necessary to build a new ditch, but because of the cost Matthew had to work along the creek. Still with hopes of finding a rich mining deposit, Matthew decided to search for deposits in other mountains, California, or New Mexico. Matthew determined that if he was able to travel west again, it would have been better if he traveled with a different company and more independently.

Description#1: After failing to successfully mine for a coal on a rented claim, Matthew was able to buy a claim along the Kansas leads. Matthew determined that the new claim has a prominent lead, but it will be difficult to begin mining the coal. Once again Matthew joined Mr. Giddings and began mining before spring. With nine new tunnels in the area, it was possible that a crushing mill will be built that will help mining during winter. At the end of his letter, Matthew explains the costs of claims, labor, and how miners work with banks.

Description#1: Matthew writes that lately there has been nothing new or interesting, but explains politics is beginning to become more popular. With a vote dealing with state or territorial government, the people were in favor of a territorial government. The recent politics has caused Matthew to believe that the local politicians are taking actions to control local government and taxes. Although there are arguments in politics, Matthew said that the weekly debates are still instructive and enjoyable. To help pass the time, Matthew asks David to send him reading material on geology and mineralogy.

Description#1: After surviving the cold weather of December, Matthew wrote that he has become healthier and stronger from mining the land. The cold December provided little snow, which benefitted the miners because the river could not wash out the creeks. While working on Mr. Giddings claims, Matthew has successfully mined quartz and could provide a fortune once the creek washes away the dirt. Although there were rumors of new and possible richer claims, Matthew advises no one to head west to mine these possible claims.

Description#1: Matthew was very glad of receiving several letters and with a new post office between the Missouri River and Denver; it resulted in a price cut on express letters. Along with the mailed letters, Matthew is glad that the miners are also receiving reading material from the Tribune and Helps Compend. [Possible reference to the Compendium of the Impending Crisis of the South: How to Meet It, by Hinton Rowan Helper (1859).] A recent duel that took place was between a representative and a secretary, which only resulted in the representative suffering a wounded defeat. Matthew is still mining quartz and wrote he is determined not to give up and hopes to find more quartz he will again search the mine.

Description#1: With the difficulties of mail routes changing, each transportation route needs to be redirected. Matthew wrote that he wanted to write more often. During the past weeks the miners had hope for success, but the majority end with disappointment. Matthew wrote about the difficulty when he could have sold land for three thousand dollars, but will only get one thousand. Responding to his mother's question on how he spends his Sundays, Matthew explains the tasks miners work on, lectures, and preaching. Because of the enjoyment he receives from letters from home, Matthew asks to continue to send letters and reading material.

Description#1: After receiving a letter from David that showed his interest in traveling west, Matthew felt it was necessary to warn David about the mining in the area. From the years of working on claims, Matthew believes that all mining has been a failure because the minerals are difficult to remove or have oxidized. With the failing mines, Matthew believes that the new jobs in the west will deal with farming. Although Matthew thinks of returning home, he wrote that every day brings new intensions.

Description#1: With nothing new to share with his family, Matthew wrote that the miners passed the time by attending union meetings and reading the news. Although the news had to travel to the Rocky Mountains, the news was printed in five days and spread in the miners in the mountains. Once again Matthew wrote about his loyalty to the government and his willingness to fight against the South. During this time Matthew was helping Thomas Giddlings start his mill and will be able to work at the mill in three to four weeks.

Description#1: While waiting to receive mail from home, Matthew wrote to his mother to use the Express Company since all the letters that he received have all been delivered from the Express Company. To continue to receive daily mail, Matthew hopes that soon a U. S. post office will be established in Denver. After learning about the growing tensions in the east, Matthew wrote his mother that although he dreads a war, his support is with the government. Matthew ends his letter by asking his mother to write about how business is being influenced by the growing tensions.

Description#1: After reading that his family has been sick and had a cold spring, Matthew wrote that he has been feeling healthier in the Rocky Mountains than in Pennsylvania. With the raining season, Matthew described that the thunder storms were remarkable to watch. Over the spring Matthew worked for Thomas Giddings, but the claim failed to provide a profit, so Mr. Giddings gave everything to his creditors. Matthew was able to become a well-paid supervisor at a mill for several months. As the mines began to fail to provide a profit, Matthew decided unless things change he will sell all his claims.

Description#1: Although Matthew planned on heading home during this time, he had to postpone his trip until he received his wages from his summer labor. With hopes of receiving his wages in a month, Matthew commented that it is difficult to collect money after it has been earned. From the money that Matthew gained, it will take three weeks to cross the plains to reach the Missouri River. Still with hopes for fortune, Matthew wrote if he does not quickly receive a job he will return to the west.
